list_page_teaser: Monty Python's John Cleese wrote and starred in Fawlty Towers, one of the best British sitcoms of all time.  Click to learn more!
description_html:
Set in the seaside town of Torquay in southern England, the British sitcom Fawlty Towers ran for just two seasons of six episodes each, in 1975 and 1979.

The show stars Monty Python's John Cleese, who wrote it with his wife (from 1968-1978) and Fawlty Towers co-star Connie Booth. The British Film Institute (BFI) ranked the show number 1 on the list of top 100 TV shows it compiled in 2000.

John Cleese got the idea for the show after he, Eric Idle, and other members of the Monty Python troupe stayed at the Gleneagles Hotel in Torquay while filming Monty Python. He based Fawlty Towers' owner and main character, Basil Fawlty, on Donald Sinclair, who was the owner of the hotel at the time of their visit.
story_html:
Filmed in front of a live audience, Fawlty Towers is a farce and full of physical humour. In commentary tracks on the DVD release Cleese frequently complains that some of the actors — particularly his wife Connie — did not hit him hard enough. One of my favorite comments of his is that one of the characters should have shown 20% more anger.

Appearing at the very top of The BFI TV 100 (2000), the show is a prime example of British humour. Based on my experience, that sort of humour is not for everyone.

These spiritual portraits show that the characters on the show are quite diverse. Nothing would please me more than to learn these images inspired someone who believes they do not care for this type of humour to give it another chance.

You can find many of the episodes online on youtube. A few of the best ones are Gourmet Night, The Germans, The Kipper and the Corpse, and Basil the Rat.

Moreover, if you give Fawlty Towers a chance and still do not care for British humour, you can say that at least you gave the best of their shows a chance.

image_list.title: Basil Fawlty
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Basil Fawlty's spiritual portrait is very colorful, showing his preferences are very slight, making it fairly easy for people to relate to his character.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Basil Fawlty's dominant personality trait, his openness to new experiences.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  In Basil's case this preference is very slight, so while the Yellow shows he is open to new experiences, the Blue shows he is also open to new ideas.  He exhibits this openness when he gets into schemes for making money.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Basil Fawlty's auxiliary personality trait, his preference for the objective.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  In Basil's case this preference is very slight, and many of the shows start off with him being fairly reasonable only to have circumstances drive him to become more and more emotional.

image_list.title: Sybil Fawlty
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Sybil Fawlty's spiritual portrait shows she is very decisive, and in the show there is no doubt that she is the one who is in charge.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Sybil's dominant personality trait, her preference for the emotional.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  In Sybil's case this preference is very slight so she can be quite rational as well.  The considerable amount of Red and Green in this image shows she is very decisive and ultimately the one who is in control.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Sybil's auxiliary personality trait, her realism.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  She demonstrates this trait in the way she tries to keep Basil down-to-earth by forbidding him from falling for risky schemes.

image_list.title: Polly Sherman
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Polly Sherman's spiritual portrait shows she is open to new ideas and treats others with compassion.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Polly's dominant personality trait, her compassion.  In Introverts, the dominant trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  She demonstrates this trait in her empathy for Basil and her willingness to help him keep his schemes secret from Sybil.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Polly's auxiliary personality trait, her preference for ideas over facts.  In Introverts, the auxiliary trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.  She demonstrates this trait when she comes up with fresh ideas for helping Basil keep Sybil from discovering his deceptions.

image_list.title: Manuel
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Manuel's spiritual portrait shows he is open to new experiences and patient with others.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Manuel's dominant personality trait, his compassion for others.  In Introverts, the dominant trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrates this trait in his care for his pet rat.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Manuel's auxiliary personality trait, his openness to new experiences.  In Introverts, the auxiliary trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.  He demonstrates this trait in the way he tries so to understand what Basil wants him to do.
